paragraphs.body: At the start of his training under Piandao, Sokka hardly knew the proper way to hold a sword. However, he had a great natural talent and progressed quickly, being able to beat the butler, ${link_0}, after a single day. Three days into his apprenticeship, Sokka and Piandao began working on making his sword. Sokka decided to make it out of a meteorite he and his friends had encountered earlier, and spent days forging the sword. After receiving this, he blew his ${link_1} cover deliberately, prompting Piandao to instigate a ${link_2} to the death, albeit fake, as a final test to make sure that Sokka had learned the necessary skills. During this fight, Sokka showed how much he had learned about the way of the sword in just a few days, showing great resourcefulness and the ability to recognize and exploit every advantage. Piandao eventually beat him, but was greatly impressed by his progress and said that Sokka had the potential to one day be an even greater master than him.

paragraphs.body: Sokka's sword is a jian, or straight sword. paragraphs.body: Since the sword was made specifically for Sokka, who also took part in its construction, the sword is "attuned" to him, suggesting a affinity between the two rather than any kind of mystical connection. Finally, the unusual material, according to Piandao, gives the sword unique properties, namely its exceptional durability and keenness; it is able to cut through thick layers of steel and other materials.

paragraphs.body: Swords and other tools forged from meteorite iron have a long history, both in the real world and in fiction. It is believed that meteorite iron was the first iron ore used by humans, before the development of mining to retrieve terrestrial iron. King Tutankhamun was entombed with a meteorite-iron dagger on his breast, and fragments from the Cape York meteorite were used by the Greenland Inuit people to fashion knife blades and harpoon heads. In more contemporary times, Japanese master swordsmith Yoshindo Yoshiwara made a katana called tentetsutou or "Sword of Heaven", the blade of which was forged from a fragment of the massive Gibeon iron meteorite that landed in Namibia in prehistoric times.
